case_vignette: A 11-year-old male with past medical history of medulloblastoma is brought to dermatology clinic for evaluation of multiple "moles" on the face, neck, arms and legs. Patient's mother reports developing similar lesions when she was younger and a history of ovarian fibromas.  Examination reveals multiple thin brown pedunculated papules on the cheeks, neck, and upper chest and back. Focal atrophic ovoid papules are appreciated on the palms bilaterally.  The patient's mother has a history of multiple "moles" and ovarian fibromas.  The patient's father has a history of multiple "moles" and melanoma.  The family history is suggestive of a possible genetic syndrome.  The patient's mother has a history of multiple "moles" and ovarian fibromas, which is suggestive of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.  The patient's father has a history of multiple "moles" and melanoma, which is suggestive of familial atypical mole melanoma syndrome. Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have multiple "moles" on my face, neck, arms, and legs.
Have these moles changed in size, shape, or color recently?
I didn't notice any recent changes in the size, shape, or color of the moles.

No, the moles do not cause any pain or discomfort.

Final Diagnosis: Dysplastic nevi

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?

Hi! I have multiple "moles" on my face, neck, arms, and legs, and some thin, brown, hanging bumps on my cheeks, neck, upper chest, and back. I also have some flat, shrinked patches on both of my palms.
Have these "moles" and other skin changes been increasing in number as you age?
Yes, these "moles" and other skin changes have been increasing as I've gotten older.
Do you have any family members with similar skin conditions or a history of skin issues?
Yes, both my mother and father have a history of multiple "moles," and my mother also had ovarian fibromas while my father had melanoma.
Have you noticed any recent changes in the color, size, or shape of these "moles"?
No, I haven't noticed any recent changes in the color, size, or shape of these "moles."
Do these skin changes cause any pain or discomfort?
No, these skin changes do not cause any pain or discomfort.
Final Diagnosis: Gorlin Syndrome (Basal Cell Nevus Syndrome)

Both of the patient's parents have a history of multiple "moles," with the mother also having had ovarian fibromas, and the father having had melanoma.
